entry.title: Building a 24-hour startup
entry.content:
It's becoming easier and faster than ever to bring an idea to market. Unfortunately, too many could-be entrepreneurs are busy crafting ideas that are everything to everyone instead of something to someone. And, in the fervor of implementation, we become overwhelmed and give up altogether. Sound familiar?

This week, I launched two new products. Yes, you read that right. I launched two products, and they're available for purchase right now. Both conceived, implemented, and marketed in less than a week. Are they fully-featured? No, not really. Will they provide value? Yes, in fact, I'm already using both myself. A product providing value already in the marketplace is worth so much more than a so-called "fully featured" product years into development that still has yet to find a customer.

There are a few criteria which separate 24-hour startups from their behemoth never-launched cousins:

  1. Build a product you would buy yourself, and sell it at a price you'd pay.

    I cannot stress this enough. If you're your own customer, you've just eliminated months of market research and collaboration prior to bringing the product to market. And, if you're willing to pay money for something you've built, you're more likely to execute effectively and others are more likely to click 'Purchase'.

  2. Build the minimum saleable version ‐ No more.

    Build a product that does one thing really, really well. A laundry list of features is no good if all of them are implemented poorly. Build the smallest saleable component of your product now, and take it to market immediately. Your customers will lead the way for the rest.

  3. Build a product which, if no units are sold, can be leveraged for other products.

    When I built my Panache! icon set product, I knew the likelyhood of becoming filthy stinking rich from icons was nil. But I was tired of using the same old icons and glyphs for my projects and wanted to give my work a unique flare. So, I outsourced their production to an Elance freelance designer and watched as my icons poured into my inbox. As soon as I made them available for sale, I immediately started in on Moola and leveraged the same icons on its marketing page.

  4. Build a product that requires minimal support and infrastructure.

    Software-as-a-service requires recurring billing infrastructure which sometimes takes as long to implement and test as the core product itself. Digital products, on the other hand, can be distributed using a one-off pricing model with no need for tracking account payments, upgrades, or cancellations. This allows you to start charging credit cards sooner rather than later.

I hope my success building microproducts will inspire you to craft your own. If you're looking for a quick way to bootstrap your new microenterprise, check out Moola, my Ruby web framework for accepting credit card payments in just ten lines of code. It includes a Getting Started guide with instructions for taking payments using Stripe and deploying on Heroku. Good luck!

entry.title: Why I quit Facebook
entry.content:
The other day, I authored a blog post entitled Stop Driving Now, which was effectively an angry rant fueled by the actions of aggressive motorists on my ride home that afternoon. Smugly, I posted it on Facebook, hoping it would attract attention. It did. I was ostracized (rightly) as an angry asshole. Comment after comment filled the link post until I finally decided to delete it. But another thing happened: I became consumed with the opinions of my peers. I had a hard time sleeping that night because I knew that my post had offended someone. And it was far from the first time this had happened.

A few weeks earlier, I encountered a post by an acquaintance thinking of joining the Marines. Being in staunch opposition to joining the military as a career choice, I voiced my concern with hope that I might change her mind. After all, the opinion of a relative stranger couldn't hurt, could it?

It could. An hour and 30 comments later, I had alienated myself from people I hadn't even met. Despite never having shared an experience to substantiate resistance, I created a situation which left everyone feeling exhausted and vulnerable.

Social media is my generation's sitcoms. Replace Jerry, Elaine, George and Kramer with four people you met at a bar a year ago, and you've effectively captured the level of triviality our Facebook feeds provide us. Even seemingly noble pursuits, whether the JCPenney fathers day ad or the Oatmeal fundraiser, have no bearing on the life we lead outside of Facebook and are better digested outside a public forum.

I've chosen to take the red pill and see how deep the rabbit hole of real life goes. See you on the other side.

If you're ready to take the plunge and delete your Facebook account permanently, visit this page in the Facebook Help Center: How do I permanently delete my account?
